title: What Does Uwu Mean? (Plus, How to Use It)

steps.title: UwU is a text emoticon used to express joy or smugness.
steps.content: UwU is a text emoticon used to express joy or smugness. Often pronounced â€œoo-uhâ€ or â€œoo-woo,â€ the emoticonâ€™s Us form closed eyes, and the W in the center makes a mouth that resembles that of an animal, such as a cat. [1] X Research source People use the symbol to say that theyâ€™re happy or content. Similarly, they may use the adorable emoticon to express a self-satisfied but good-natured smugness. [2] X Research source â€œUwUâ€ is also sometimes known as the â€œhappy anime face,â€ thanks to its prolific use in anime and anime-related communities. â€œuwu, I canâ€™t wait to see the movie.â€ â€œI managed to snatch the last donut! UwUâ€

steps.title: Girls might use â€œuwuâ€ to express appreciation for something cute.
steps.content: Girls might use â€œuwuâ€ to express appreciation for something cute. Perhaps most commonly, â€œuwuâ€ is used in reaction to something cute, like a photo of an adorable kitten or an especially round plushy. [3] X Research source When a girl says it in this context, she wants you to know sheâ€™s melting with cuteness overload. You: â€œTake a look at this pic of my new puppy.â€ Her: â€œOMG sheâ€™s so precious!! uwuâ€

steps.title: A girl might also use â€œuwuâ€ to convey bashfulness.
steps.content: A girl might also use â€œuwuâ€ to convey bashfulness. Among uwuâ€™s many uses, some girls also use it to express shyness or a cute sort of sheepishness. This is often accompanied by the â€œğŸ‘‰ğŸ‘ˆâ€ emojis, which convey a pleading or demure meekness. [4] X Research source â€œHey, can we hang out soon? uwu ğŸ‘‰ğŸ‘ˆâ€ â€œJust wanted to let you know that I think youâ€™re kinda cute uwuâ€

steps.title: UwU may have roots in Japanese â€œkawaiiâ€ culture.
steps.content: UwU may have roots in Japanese â€œkawaiiâ€ culture. â€œKawaiiâ€ (literally â€œcuteâ€) culture is, in a nutshell, a social scene centered on all things adorableâ€“things like cute clothing, animals, or mascot characters. The subculture is known for its prolific use of various emojis and emoticons, and while nobody can say for certain itâ€™s responsible for â€œuwu,â€ the face has found prolific use among kawaii scene members. [5] X Research source The term may also be related to â€œkaomoji,â€ which are emojis that utilize Japanese characters and are often considered especially cute.

steps.title: UwU went viral on Tumblr in 2013, boosting its popularity.
steps.content: UwU went viral on Tumblr in 2013, boosting its popularity. A conversation between users on the microblogging platform Tumblr showcased the emoticon, clarifying the symbolâ€™s resemblance to a face. The conversation went viral, promoting widespread use of the emoticon on the platform and beyond. [6] X Research source The first recorded use of â€œuwuâ€ was in a fanfiction related to the popular anime Yu-Gi-Oh , published in 2005. [7] X Research source Uwu was first defined on UrbanDictionary in 2012, described as â€œanother way of typing the smiley face :3, TwT or twt. It means happy, like an anime character's face when they're overjoyed." [8] X Research source The face was no doubt used in chat rooms and forums long before the UrbanDictionary entry or the Tumblr post, but pinning down its exact origin is a task lost to the vast intricacies of the internet.

steps.title: UwU is often used by fandom members.
steps.content: UwU is often used by fandom members. While the term has slipped into the mainstream, itâ€™s often used particularly in fandom circlesâ€”groups dedicated to following things like a TV show or a K-pop group. Here, people use uwu to express appreciation for certain characters, or just how they feel about a recent episode. â€œThe new BTS music video has me like uwu.â€ â€œWhen Michael professed his love on last nightâ€™s episodeâ€¦ uwu.â€

steps.title: UwU is often used by â€œe-girlsâ€ or members of â€œhyper-cuteâ€ subcultures.
steps.content: UwU is often used by â€œe-girlsâ€ or members of â€œhyper-cuteâ€ subcultures. An â€œe-girlâ€ is an online personality fashioned after soft or cute aesthetics. â€œUwu girlsâ€ are e-girls who have adopted both the emoticon and its cutesy connotations to an extreme extent, often speaking and acting with exaggerated innocence or with juvenile mannerisms perceived as cute. [9] X Research source The â€œuwu girlâ€ is often most active on Discord, a chat room service popular among video game players. This subculture often veers into sexualized or otherwise mature territory.

steps.title: Others use the term facetiously or generally dislike it.
steps.content: Others use the term facetiously or generally dislike it. Like any internet phenomena, where there are enthusiasts, there are also naysayers. Many internet users use the emoticon sarcastically, as a means to poke fun at it. Others express concern that â€œuwu cultureâ€ might promote predatory dynamics among users via its â€œcute-speakâ€ usage. [10] X Research source â€œUgh, donâ€™t go all uwu on me.â€

steps.title: Use â€œuwuâ€ to express happiness or to say that something is adorable.
steps.content: Use â€œuwuâ€ to express happiness or to say that something is adorable. The average internet denizen uses â€œuwuâ€ simply to convey contentment, or to react to something positively delightful and totes adorbs. [11] X Research source â€œHad to show off my outfit because Iâ€™m looking so nice today uwuâ€ â€œSaw the most uwu kitty on my ride to work.â€

steps.title: Show your smugness with a lighthearted uwu.
steps.content: Show your smugness with a lighthearted uwu. Another common usage for uwu is to make good fun of either your own victories or your friendâ€™s not-too-serious defeats. Itâ€™s especially handy when youâ€™re doing or saying something fun at your friendâ€™s expense. â€œSorry gang, I canâ€™t help that I keep winning. uwuâ€ â€œIâ€™m only this annoying because I like you so much, uwuâ€

steps.title: Use â€œuwuâ€ to convey shyness.
steps.content: Use â€œuwuâ€ to convey shyness. You might also use â€œuwuâ€ to show someone that youâ€™re a bit bashful or reserved. Not in a terribly painful or awkward way, but in a soft, unserious kind of way. This is often the case when youâ€™re asking for something from the other person. â€œWould you pretty please give me a super quick ride to the airport? uwuâ€ â€œWhich dress do you think looks cuter on me? uwuâ€

steps.title: Respond to uwu with a similar cutesy tone.
steps.content: Respond to uwu with a similar cutesy tone. If someone hits you with that â€œuwu,â€ theyâ€™re shifting into a playful, lighthearted gear. If youâ€™re feeling it, match that energy and play along. You donâ€™t have to go full baby talk, but donâ€™t be afraid to work the vibe. Them: â€œIsnâ€™t Mittens so cute? UwU, I could just eat her up.â€ You: â€œMittens is the cutest kitty Iâ€™ve ever seen! uwuâ€

steps.title: OwO
steps.content: OwO A variation of the same face, but with the eyes wide open. Often used like a wide-eyed, blank stare, like when a cat is about to pounce. [12] X Research source Denotes surprise or focused attention. â€œowo Whatâ€™s that smell? Steak?â€

steps.title: T_T
steps.content: T_T A sad face, with 2 streams of tears running toward a flat mouth. Used to indicate sadness. [13] X Research source Note that the similar face TwT represents tears of joy, with a cute smile. â€œI just dropped my steak T_Tâ€
^ - ^ Two closed, smiling eyes with a small, cute mouth. This face often accompanies cheerful messages. â€œDonâ€™t worry, you can have my steak! ^ - ^â€

steps.title: â€“_â€“
steps.content: â€“_â€“ Two flat, closed eyes with a flat mouth. This emoticon expresses dry, anticlimactic disappointment or detachment. â€œI dropped the second steak â€“_â€“â€
